original: 1. Iddhipāṭihāriya

original: Katamāni tīṇi?
analyzed: katamāni tīṇi

analyzed: hoti bahudhā api hutvā ekaḥ hoti āvi bhāvam tirobhāvam tiro kuṭṭam tiro pākāram tiro pabbata  a sajjamānaḥ gacchati sā iyathā api ākāse pathaviyā api ummujja nimujjam karoti sā iyathā api  udake udake pi abhijjamāne gacchati seyyathā api pathaviye ākāse pi pallaṅkena kamati  seyyathā api pakkhī sakuṇaḥ ime api candima sūriye evam mahiddhike evam mahā anubhāve pāṇinā
translated: He becomes many,

analyzed: parāmasati parimajjati yāva brahma lokā api kāyena vasam vatta iti

He travels cross-legged through the air like a bird on the wing. He even touches and strokes the moon and sun, so mighty and powerful, with his hand. He wields bodily mastery even as far as the Brahmā world.

original: Tamenaṁ aññataro saddho pasanno passati taṁ bhikkhuṁ anekavihitaṁ iddhividhaṁ paccanubhontaṁ—ekopi🔽hutvā bahudhā hontaṁ, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hontaṁ; āvibhāvaṁ tirobhāvaṁ; tirokuṭṭaṁ

analyzed: tiro upākāram tiro pabbatam a sajjamānam gacchantam seyyathā api ākāse pathaviyā api ummujja nimujja
translated: multiplying himself and becoming one again; appearing and disappearing; going unhindered through walls, through enclosures, through mountains as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if through water; traveling cross-legged through the air like a bird on the wing; even touching and stroking the moon and sun, so mighty and powerful, with his hand; wielding bodily mastery even as far as the Brahmā world.

original: karontaṁ seyyathāpi udake; udakepi abhijjamāne gacchantaṁ seyyathāpi pathaviyaṁ;🔽ākāsepi pallaṅkena kamantaṁ seyyathāpi pakkhī sakuṇo; imepi candimasūriye evaṁ mahiddhike
analyzed: karontam sā iyathā api udake udake pi abhijjamāne gacchantam sā iyathā api  ākāse pi pallaṅkena kamantam seyyathā api pakkhī sakuṇaḥ ime pi candima sūriye evam mahiddhike
translated: and walking on water as on land;

translated: And he tells someone who has faith and confidence in him,

analyzed: acchariyam vata bho abbhutam vata bho samaṇassa mahiddhika tā mahā anubhāva tā
translated: ‘It’s incredible, it’s amazing, the great power and great might of the Buddha!🔽I saw a monk exercising the various kinds of psychic power: multiplying himself and becoming one again;

original: Amāhaṁ bhikkhuṁ addasaṁ anekavihitaṁ iddhividhaṁ paccanubhontaṁ—ekopi hutvā bahudhā hontaṁ, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hontaṁ …pe… yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṁ vattentan’ti.
analyzed: amā aham bhikkhum addasam aneka vihitam iddhi vidham paccanubhonta ekaḥ api hutvā bahudhā honta bahudhā api hutvā ekaḥ hontam pe yāva brahma lokā api kāyena vasam
translated: and even exercising mastery with his body as far as the Brahmā world.’

analyzed: tam enam saḥ assaddhaḥ appasannaḥ tam saddham pasannam evam vadeyya
translated: But the one without faith and confidence says to him,

translated: ‘There’s a spell called “The Gandhārī”.

translated: With that he enjoys various supernormal powers: having been one he becomes many; having been many he becomes one … he exercises mastery with the body as far as the brahmā world.’

original: Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, kevaṭṭa,

translated: “Seeing this danger in the miracle of supernormal power, I am repelled, humiliated, and disgusted by the miracle of supernormal power.

original: 2. Ādesanāpāṭihāriya
analyzed: ādesanā pāṭihāriya
translated: The miracle of telepathy

translated: “And what, Kevatta, is the miracle of telepathy?🔽Here, Kevatta, a bhikkhu reveals the minds of other beings, of other persons, reads the minds of other beings, of other persons.

analyzed: evam pi te manaḥ ittham pi te manaḥ iti pi te cittanti
translated: and the mind without passion as without passion;

original: Tamenaṁ so saddho pasanno aññatarassa assaddhassa appasannassa āroceti:
analyzed: tam enam saḥ saddhaḥ pasannaḥ aññatarassa assaddhassa appasannassa āroceti
translated: And he tells a certain faithless and unconfident person about this,

original: ‘acchariyaṁ vata bho, abbhutaṁ vata bho, samaṇassa mahiddhikatā mahānubhāvatā.🔽Amāhaṁ bhikkhuṁ addasaṁ parasattānaṁ parapuggalānaṁ cittampi ādisantaṁ, cetasikampi ādisantaṁ, vitakkitampi ādisantaṁ, vicāritampi ādisantaṁ:
analyzed: acchariyam vata bho abbhutam vata bho samaṇassa mahiddhika tā mahā anubhāva tā  amā aham bhikkhum addasam para sattānam para puggalānam cittam pi ādisanta cetasikam pi ādisanta vitakkitam pi ādisanta vicāritam pi ādisanta
translated: saying: ‘It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing, how powerful and mighty is the contemplative’s magic power and his ability to read the minds of other beings, other persons!🔽I myself saw that monk mind-reading about the minds of other beings, other persons,

original: “evampi te mano, itthampi te mano, itipi te cittan”’ti.
analyzed: evam pi te manaḥ ittham pi te manaḥ iti pi te cittanti
translated: saying: “So it is with your mind, so it was with your mind, so it will be with your mind. Thus internally, so externally. Thus both internally and externally. Thus with a focus on form… Thus with a focus on whatever is not-self.”’

original: Tamenaṁ so assaddho appasanno taṁ saddhaṁ pasannaṁ evaṁ vadeyya:
analyzed: tam enam saḥ assaddhaḥ appasannaḥ tam saddham pasannam evam vadeyya
translated: Then that faithless and unconfident person says to that faithful and confident person,

original: ‘atthi kho, bho, maṇikā nāma vijjā;
analyzed: atthi kho bho maṇikā nāma vijjā
translated: ‘There is, my good man, a spell called the jewel.

original: tāya so bhikkhu parasattānaṁ parapuggalānaṁ cittampi ādisati, cetasikampi ādisati, vitakkitampi ādisati, vicāritampi ādisati:
analyzed: tāya saḥ bhikkhu para sattānam para puggalānam cittam api ādisati cetasikam api ādisati vitakkitam api ādisati vicāritam api ādisati
translated: That monk can read the minds of other beings, of other persons,

original: “evampi te mano, itthampi te mano, itipi te cittan”’ti.
analyzed: evam pi te manaḥ ittham pi te manaḥ iti pi te cittanti
translated: and can tell them: ‘This is what you’re thinking, this is what you’re contemplating, this is what you’re imagining.’

original: Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, kevaṭṭa,

translated: “Yes, lord.”

analyzed: imam kho aha kevaṭṭaḥ ādesanā pāṭihāriye ādīnavam sampassamānaḥ ādesanā pāṭihāriyena aṭṭīyāmi harāyāmi jigucchāmi
translated: “Seeing the danger in this miracle of instruction, I am disgusted with the miracle of instruction.

original: 3. Anusāsanīpāṭihāriya
analyzed: anusāsanīpāṭihāriya
translated: The Miracle of Teaching

original: Katamañca, kevaṭṭa, anusāsanīpāṭihāriyaṁ?

translated: This is called the miracle of teaching.

translated: This is the sign of the great Brahmā’s appearance: a light appears.

original: Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, mahābrahmā nacirasseva pāturahosi.
analyzed: atha kho saḥ kevaṭṭa mahābrahmā nacirassa iva pātuḥ ahosi
translated: ’ Then, Kevatta, not long after the great Brahmā had disappeared,

original: Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu yena so mahābrahmā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṁ mahābrahmānaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho saḥ kevaṭṭa bhikkhu yena saḥ mahābrahmā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā tam mahābrahmānam etat avoca
translated: the monk went to him and said:

original: ‘kattha nu kho, āvuso, ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṁ—pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti?
analyzed: kattha nu kho āvuso ime cattāraḥ mahābhūtāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti seyyathida pathavī dhātu āpaḥ dhātu tejaḥ dhātu vāyo dhātu uti
translated: ‘Where do the four great elements — the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element — cease without remainder?’

original: Evaṁ vutte, kevaṭṭa, so mahābrahmā taṁ bhikkhuṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte kevaṭṭa saḥ mahābrahmā tam bhikkhum etat avoca
translated: When this was said, Kevatta, the Great Brahma said to the monk,

original: ‘ahamasmi, bhikkhu, brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānan’ti.
analyzed: aham asmi bhikkhu brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūtaḥ añña datthudasaḥ vasa vattī issaraḥ kattā nimmātā seṭṭhaḥ sa jitā vasī pitā
translated: ‘I, monk, am Brahma, the Great Brahma, the Conqueror, the Unconquered, the All-Seeing, the All-Powerful, the Lord, the Maker and Creator, the Supreme Being, the Ordainer, the Almighty, the Father of All That Have Been and Shall Be.’

original: Dutiyampi kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu taṁ mahābrahmānaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: dutiyam pi kho saḥ kevaṭṭa bhikkhu tam mahābrahmānam etat avoca
translated: For a second time, Kevatta, the monk said to the Great Brahma,

original: ‘na khohaṁ taṁ, āvuso, evaṁ pucchāmi:
analyzed: na kha uham te āvuso evam pucchāmi
translated: ‘I’m not asking you, friend,

original: “tvamasi brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānan”ti.
analyzed: tvam asi brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūtaḥ vasavattī issaraḥ kattā nimmātā seṭṭhaḥ sajitā vasī pitā
translated: if you are Brahma, the Great Brahma, the Conqueror, the Unconquered, the All-Seeing, the All-Powerful, the Lord, the Maker and Creator, the Supreme Being, the Ordainer, the Almighty, the Father of All That Have Been and Shall Be.

original: Evañca kho ahaṁ taṁ, āvuso, pucchāmi:
analyzed: evam ca kho aham te āvuso pucchāmi
translated: But I’m asking you this:

original: “kattha nu kho, āvuso, ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṁ—pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū”’ti?
analyzed: kattha nu kho āvuso ime cattāraḥ mahābhūtāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti seyyathida pathavī dhātu āpaḥ dhātu tejaḥ dhātu vāyo dhātu uti
translated: “Where do the four great elements — the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element — cease without remainder?”

original: Dutiyampi kho so, kevaṭṭa, mahābrahmā taṁ bhikkhuṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: dutiyam pi kho saḥ kevaṭṭa mahābrahmā tam bhikkhum etat avoca
translated: For a second time, the Great Brahma told the monk,

original: ‘ahamasmi, bhikkhu, brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānan’ti.
analyzed: aham asmi bhikkhu brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūtaḥ añña datthudasaḥ vasa vattī issaraḥ kattā nimmātā seṭṭhaḥ sa jitā vasī pitā
translated: “I am Brahma, the Great Brahma, the Conqueror, the Unconquered, the All-Seeing, All-Powerful, the Lord, the Maker and Creator, the Supreme Being, the Ordainer, the Almighty, the Father of All That Have Been and Shall Be.”

original: Tatiyampi kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu taṁ mahābrahmānaṁ etadavoca:🔽‘na khohaṁ taṁ, āvuso, evaṁ pucchāmi:
analyzed: tatiyam pi kho saḥ kevaṭṭa bhikkhu tam mahābrahmānam etat avoca  na kha uham te āvuso evam pucchāmi
translated: For a third time, the monk told the Great Brahma,

original: “tvamasi brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānan”ti.🔽Evañca kho ahaṁ taṁ, āvuso, pucchāmi:
analyzed: tvam asi brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūtaḥ vasavattī issaraḥ kattā nimmātā seṭṭhaḥ sajitā vasī pitā 🔽evam ca kho aham te āvuso pucchāmi
translated: “I’m not asking you if you are Brahma, the Great Brahma, the Conqueror, the Unconquered, the All-Seeing, All-Powerful, the Lord, the Maker and Creator, the Supreme Being, the Ordainer, the Almighty, the Father of All That Have Been and Shall Be.🔽I’m asking you where the four great elements — the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element — cease without remainder.”

original: “kattha nu kho, āvuso, ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṁ—pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū”’ti?
analyzed: kattha nu kho āvuso ime cattāraḥ mahābhūtāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti seyyathida pathavī dhātu āpaḥ dhātu tejaḥ dhātu vāyo dhātu uti
translated: “Where do the four great elements — the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element — cease without remainder?”

original: Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, mahābrahmā taṁ bhikkhuṁ bāhāyaṁ gahetvā ekamantaṁ apanetvā taṁ bhikkhuṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho saḥ kevaṭṭa mahābrahmā tam bhikkhum bāhāyam gahetvā eka mantam apanetvā tam bhikkhum etat avoca
translated: Then, Kevatta, the Great Brahma took that monk by the arm, led him to one side and said to him:

original: ‘ime kho maṁ, bhikkhu, brahmakāyikā devā evaṁ jānanti, “natthi kiñci brahmuno aññātaṁ,
analyzed: ime kho ma bhikkhu brahmakāyikāḥ devāḥ evam jānanti natthi kiñci brahmunaḥ
translated: ‘Monks, these Brahma gods know me thus: “There is nothing unknown to Brahma,

original: natthi kiñci brahmuno adiṭṭhaṁ, natthi kiñci brahmuno aviditaṁ, natthi kiñci brahmuno asacchikatan”ti.
analyzed: natthi kiñci brahmuno natthi kiñci brahmuno a vidita natthi kiñci brahmuno
translated: there is nothing unseen by Brahma, there is nothing unheard by Brahma, there is nothing unsensed by Brahma, there is nothing uncognized by Brahma.”

original: Tasmāhaṁ tesaṁ sammukhā na byākāsiṁ.
analyzed: tasmā aham tesam sammukhā na
translated: That is why I did not answer you in your presence.

original: Ahampi kho, bhikkhu, na jānāmi yatthime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṁ—pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātūti.
analyzed: aham pi kho bhikkhu na jānāmi yattha ime cattāraḥ mahābhūtāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti seyyathida pathavī dhātu āpaḥ dhātu tejaḥ dhātu vāyo dhātu uti
translated: But, monk, I do not know where the four great elements — the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element — cease without remainder.’

original: Tasmātiha, bhikkhu, tuyhevetaṁ dukkaṭaṁ, tuyhevetaṁ aparaddhaṁ, yaṁ tvaṁ taṁ bhagavantaṁ atidhāvitvā bahiddhā pariyeṭṭhiṁ āpajjasi imassa pañhassa veyyākaraṇāya.
analyzed: tasmā atiha bhikkhu tuyhā iva etam dukkaṭa tuyhā iva etam aparaddha yam tvam tam bhagavantam atidhāvitvā bahiddhā pariyeṭṭhim āpajjasi imassa pañhassa veyyākaraṇāya
translated: Therefore, bhikkhu, it is you who are asking too much if you ask me to explain this matter further.

original: Gaccha tvaṁ, bhikkhu, tameva bhagavantaṁ upasaṅkamitvā imaṁ pañhaṁ puccha, yathā ca te bhagavā byākaroti, tathā naṁ dhāreyyāsī’ti.
analyzed: gaccha tva bhikkhu tam eva bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā imam pañham puccha yathā ca te bhagavā byākaroti tathā nam dhāreyyāsi iti
translated: Therefore, bhikkhu, it is you who should go to the Blessed One and ask him about this riddle. As the Blessed One tells you, so should you remember it.”

original: Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṁ vā bāhaṁ pasāreyya, pasāritaṁ vā bāhaṁ samiñjeyya; evameva brahmaloke antarahito mama purato pāturahosi.
analyzed: atha kho saḥ kevaṭṭa bhikkhu seyyathā api nāma balavā purisaḥ samiñjitam vā bāham pasāreyya pasāritam vā bāham samiñjeyya evam eva brahma loke antarahitaḥ mama puratas pātuḥ ahosi
translated: Then, Kevatta, just as a strong man might extend his flexed arm or flex his extended arm, so too, that bhikkhu disappeared from the brahma world and reappeared in my presence.

original: Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu maṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi, ekamantaṁ nisinno kho, kevaṭṭa, so bhikkhu maṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho saḥ kevaṭṭa bhikkhu mam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho kevaṭṭa saḥ bhikkhu mam etat avoca
translated: Then, Kevatta, that bhikkhu paid homage to me, sat down to one side, and reported his entire conversation with the brahma Utpala-vakka.

original: ‘kattha nu kho, bhante, ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṁ—pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti?
analyzed: kattha nu kho bhante ime cattāraḥ mahābhūtāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti seyyathida pathavī dhātu āpaḥ dhātu tejaḥ dhātu vāyo dhātu uti
translated: ‘Where do the four great elements — the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element — cease without remainder?’

original: 4.1. Tīradassisakuṇupamā
analyzed: tīra dassi sakuṇupamā
translated: … The simile of the sea bird

original: Evaṁ vutte, ahaṁ, kevaṭṭa, taṁ bhikkhuṁ etadavocaṁ—
analyzed: evam vutte aha kevaṭṭa tam bhikkhum etat avoca
translated: When that was said, I told the monk,

original: bhūtapubbaṁ, bhikkhu, sāmuddikā vāṇijā tīradassiṁ sakuṇaṁ gahetvā nāvāya samuddaṁ ajjhogāhanti.
analyzed: bhūta pubba bhikkhu sāmuddikāḥ vāṇijāḥ tīra dassim sakuṇam gahetvā nāvāya samuddaṃ ajjhogāhanti
translated: ‘Once, monk, seafaring merchants caught a sea bird and took it out to sea in a boat.

original: Te atīradakkhiniyā nāvāya tīradassiṁ sakuṇaṁ muñcanti.
analyzed: te a tīra dakkhiniyā nāvāya tīra dassim sakuṇam muñcanti
translated: When they were out of sight of land, they released the bird.

original: So gacchateva puratthimaṁ disaṁ, gacchati dakkhiṇaṁ disaṁ, gacchati pacchimaṁ disaṁ, gacchati uttaraṁ disaṁ, gacchati uddhaṁ disaṁ, gacchati anudisaṁ.
analyzed: saḥ gacchatā iva puratthimam disa gacchati dakkhiṇam disa gacchati pacchimam disa gacchati uttaram disa gacchati uddham disa gacchati anudisa
translated: It flew off in the eastern direction, but came back. It flew off in the same way in the southern, western, and northern directions, and also up and down.

original: Sace so samantā tīraṁ passati, tathāgatakova hoti.
analyzed: sace so samantā tīram passati tathāgatakaḥ uva hoti
translated: If it saw land in any direction, it flew off in that direction, but came back.

original: Sace pana so samantā tīraṁ na passati, tameva nāvaṁ paccāgacchati.
analyzed: sace pana so samantā tīram na passati tam eva nāvam paccāgacchati
translated: If it didn’t see land in any direction, it came back to the boat.

original: Evameva kho tvaṁ, bhikkhu, yato yāva brahmalokā pariyesamāno imassa pañhassa veyyākaraṇaṁ nājjhagā, atha mamaññeva santike paccāgato.
analyzed: evam eva kho tva bhikkhu yatas yāva brahmalokā pariyesamāno imassa pañhassa veyyākaraṇam na ajjhagāḥ atha mamaññā iva santike paccāgataḥ
translated: In the same way, you have come back to me, having searched as far as the world of Brahmā and not finding an answer to your question.

original: Na kho eso, bhikkhu, pañho evaṁ pucchitabbo:
analyzed: na kho eso bhikkhu pañhaḥ evam pucchitabbaḥ
translated: “Bhikkhu, this question should not be asked thus:

original: ‘kattha nu kho, bhante, ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṁ—pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti?
analyzed: kattha nu kho bhante ime cattāraḥ mahābhūtāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti seyyathida pathavī dhātu āpaḥ dhātu tejaḥ dhātu vāyo dhātu uti
translated: ‘Venerable sir, where do the four great elements cease without remainder—that is, the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element?’

original: Evañca kho eso, bhikkhu, pañho pucchitabbo:
analyzed: evam ca kho eso bhikkhu pañhaḥ pucchitabbo
translated: This question should be asked thus:

original: ‘Kattha āpo ca pathavī,
analyzed: katthaḥ āpaḥ ca pathavī
translated: ‘Where does earth, where does water,

original: tejo vāyo na gādhati;
analyzed: tejaḥ vāyo na gādhati
translated: Where does fire, where does air not prevail?

original: Kattha dīghañca rassañca,🔽aṇuṁ thūlaṁ subhāsubhaṁ;
analyzed: kattha dīghan ca rassan ca  aṇum thūlam subha asubha
translated: Where is long, where is short,🔽Where is gross, where is fine?

original: Kattha nāmañca rūpañca,
analyzed: kattha nāmañca rūpañca
translated: Where is name-and-form

original: asesaṁ uparujjhatī’ti.
analyzed: asesam uparujjhati iti
translated: Completely dissolved away?’

original: Tatra veyyākaraṇaṁ bhavati:
analyzed: tatra veyyākaraṇam bhavati
translated: “The answer to that question is as follows:

original: ‘Viññāṇaṁ anidassanaṁ,
analyzed: viññāṇam anidassana
translated: ‘Consciousness, signless,

original: anantaṁ sabbatopabhaṁ;
analyzed: anantam sabbata upabha
translated: infinite, all-luminous,

original: Ettha āpo ca pathavī,
analyzed: ettha āpaḥ ca pathavī
translated: Here earth, here water,

original: tejo vāyo na gādhati.
analyzed: tejaḥ vāyo na gādhati
translated: Here fire, here air do not prevail.

original: Ettha dīghañca rassañca,
analyzed: ettha dīghañ ca rassañ ca
translated: Here long, here short,

original: aṇuṁ thūlaṁ subhāsubhaṁ;
analyzed: aṇum thūlam subha asubha
translated: Here gross, here fine,

original: Ettha nāmañca rūpañca,
analyzed: ettha nāman ca rūpañca
translated: Here name-and-form

original: asesaṁ uparujjhati;
analyzed: asesam uparujjhati
translated: completely ceases.

original: Viññāṇassa nirodhena,
analyzed: viññāṇassa nirodhena
translated: With the cessation of consciousness,

original: etthetaṁ uparujjhatī’”ti.
analyzed: ettha itam uparujjhati iti
translated: that is where this all ceases.”

original: Idamavoca bhagavā.
analyzed: idam avoca bhagavān
translated: The Buddha said this.

original: Attamano kevaṭṭo gahapatiputto bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.
analyzed: atta manaḥ kevaṭṭaḥ gahapati putto bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinandi iti
translated: Kevaṭṭa, the son of the house-master, was satisfied and delighted in what the Buddha said.

original: Kevaṭṭasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ ekādasamaṁ.
analyzed: kevaṭṭa suttam niṭṭhitam ekādasama
translated: The Kevaṭṭa Sutta is finished.
